text: An afternoon in late November, the leaves have left the trees, and the early darkness of a winter dusk approaches The garden is long and narrow, guarded on either side by high brick wall. At one end stands the rear of a three-st brick townhouse; at the other, a one story brick building CLASSICAL MUSIC is heard in the distance. A MAN, handsome dressed in a well-tailored suit of the 1920's, works in t garden. A gardener's apron protects his suit from the ear as he turns the loam along one of the walkways. He works slowly,-precisely, obviously engrossed in his surrounding This man is called CHANCE. Chance stops working for a moment, takes a pocket watch f inside his coat, checks the time. He looks to the darkeni skies, returns the watch to his pocket. As Chance starts toward the one story brick building, he takes a spotless from his apron pocket and wipes the dirt from the tines o his pitchfork.

The sound of the music increases as Chance enters the gar from the garden. A gleaming 1921 TOURING CAR is revealed he walks through the garage and leans the pitchfork again wall. Chance takes a neatly folded cover from a shelf, carefully puts it over the car. When he finishes covering car for the night, Chance picks up the pitchfork, leaves garage through a side entry.

The Potting Room is filled with the tools of the gardener everything arranged in an orderly fashion. Rows of small are on tables, young plants sprouting from some of them. small, 1940's table model black-and-white TV rests on a shelf. It is playing, tuned to the BOSTON POPS ORCHESTRA. Attached to the front of the screen is a wheel containing colored gels. The wheels spins, creates an early form of color TV. As Chance enters, his attention is on the television set. He watches it as he oils the tines of the pitchfork and puts it away. Chance turns off the TV and leaves the room, but the sound of the Boston Pops continu

A room adjacent to the Potting Room. A large screen remot control color television set dominates the room. It is on tuned to the Boston Pops. In contrast to the new TV, the of the room is sparsely but tastefully decorated with expensive furniture of the twenties. There are no books, magazines, newspapers or reading matter of any kind to be seen. Chance comes in, watches the TV with a detached gaz he removes his apron. He changes the channel with the rem control as he puts his apron and the pitchfork rag into a laundry bag. He takes off his suit jacket, hangs it in th closet where it is accompanied by several others, all of quality. Chance changes the channel once again.
Chance, wearing a different suit and carrying the laundry bag, crosses from the rear building to the main house.
The interior of the main house has the mustiness of age, warmth of oak. White dropcloths and sheets cover all of t furniture. Chance enters, walks through the hallway.

A large dropcloth is over the dining room table and chair It is neatly folded back at one end, leaving one chair an place setting uncovered. A small portable color TV is nex the place setting. Chance enters, puts his laundry bag on a covered table ne the doorway. He sits at the dining room table, turns on t TV, and carefully unfolds his napkin, puts it on his lap he watches the screen. LOUISE, an elderly black maid, ent with a tray of food and Chance's clean laundry.
(sets dinner before Chance)
... Evening, Chance.
(slowly, perfect diction, no accent of any kind)
... Good evening, Louise. Louise sets Chance's clean clothes on the small table, pi up his laundry bag.
... The Old Man is getting weaker, Chance.
(begins to eat)
I see.
I'm afraid he's slippin' a bit with every hour that goes by... Chance, his manners impeccable, concentrates on the TV as eats. A buzzer SOUNDS, Louise looks upstairs.
... Back up those stairs - damn... That Man's needin' me more and more just before he never needs me again...
(still watches TV)
Is his back feeling better? Louise gives Chance a look.
... Gobbledegook... You and your gobbledegook. You're gonna be the death of me yet, Chance... (she turns to leave)

... Unless those stairs are... The Good Lord's liable to snatch up two unwillin' souls at the same time if I keep on trampin' up those stairs... I don't want none of that... Louise disappears through the doorway. Chance continues t eat and watch TV.

Chance is asleep, lying on his back. His eyes slowly open and, with no change of expression, he sits up and turns o the TV with the remote control. Chance gets out of bed, g to the dresser and takes his pocket watch out of a drawer checks the time. He crosses to the closet, his eyes never straying from an early morning show on television. He put a bathrobe and leaves the room.
Chance enters, turns on the TV with the spinning color wh then waters a few of the pots with a sprinkling can. He t off the TV and exits.
Chance comes into the garage, takes the cover off of the touring car, folds it and puts it on a shelf. He leaves t garage.
Chance returns to his room, changes channels on the television, takes off his robe and hangs it back up in th closet, then goes into the bathroom.

A light snow is falling. The door to the small building opens, Chance peeks out, then goes back inside. A few sec pass and Chance reappears, this time with an umbrella. Smartly dressed in suit and tie, he crosses to the main house.
Chance opens the door, shakes off and closes the umbrella before entering. He hangs the umbrella on a doorknob, the heads for the dining room.

Repeating his ritual, Chance enters the dining room, sits turns on the TV, carefully spreads his napkin on his lap. watches the screen for a moment, then turns, expecting Louise. She doesn't appear, so he turns back, watches TV. After a few beats, Chance hears Louise's footsteps hurryi down the stairs. She comes into the dining room, visibly distraught. Chance looks up, smiles.
Good morning, Louise.
(out of breath)
He's dead, Chance! The Old Man's dead!
(flatly, turns back to TV)
... I see.

Must of happened durin' the night, I don't know... Lord, he wasn't breathin' and as cold as a fish. I touched him, just to see, and you believe me, Chance - that's doin' more than I get paid to do... Then I just covered him up, pulled the sheet over his head...
(nodding)
Yes. I've seen that done.

Then I got the hell out of that room and called the doctor and I think I woke him probably, he wasn't any too alert. He just said, 'Yeah, he's been expectin' it and said he'd send somebody over...' Lord, what a mornin'!
(watches news, flashes of season's first snowfall)
... Yes, Louise, it's snowing in the garden today. Have you looked outside and seen the snow? It's very white. A beat of silence from Louise, then anger.
Dammit, Boy! Is that all you got to say? More gobbledegook?  (Chance smiles, is silent)
That Old Man's layin' up there dead as hell and it just don't make any difference to you!
(with a smile, accepting death)
Yes, Louise. I have seen it often. It happens to old people.
Well, ain't that the truth...
Yes. It is. Louise throws back the cover from a chair next to Chance sits, softening a bit toward him.
Oh, Lord, Chance - I don't know what I was expectin' from you... I'm sorry for yellin' like I did... No sir, I just don't know what I was expectin' ...  (Chance doesn't react, watches TV)
... I 'spose I'd better gather up some breakfast for you...
(a turn to her)
Yes, I'm very hungry.
(rises, looks upstairs)
Well, no more stewin' those prunes every mornin', that's somethin', I guess...  (she starts out, stops by the door)
... what are you goin' to do now, Chance?
(gazing at TV)
I'm going to work in the garden. Louise gives Chance a long look, then turns to leave.
(as she goes)
... I'll get you some eggs. Chance nods in approval, then changes the channel on the
An enclosed stairway. Chance enters, proceeds up the stai
Chance comes out of a doorway adjoining the main staircas He moves off down the hall.

The furniture in this room is not covered with sheets but Old Man is. There is a polite knock at the door, then Cha enters the room. As Chance moves slowly to the Old Man's we sense a feeling of respect from Chance, as well as a b of curiosity. Chance stands by the side of the bed for a moment, then he reaches down and gently pulls the sheet b from the Old Man's face. He touches the man's forehead, lightly, briefly, then replaces the sheet. Chance moves t the TV (like the one in his own room) and turns it on. He sits in an easy chair next to the Old man's bed and watch movie from the early forties. Chance puts an arm out, res it on the Old Man's covered body. With the other, he chan the channels with the remote control. He returns to the channel with the forties movie and seem become absorbed in a scene in which a gentleman tips his to a lady. The scene seems to have 'sunk into' his mind.

It has stopped snowing. Chance, wearing a hat, the garden apron over his suit and boots, putters in the garden. Lou comes out of the main house. She is dressed warmly, a sca over her head, a heavy coat. Chance sees her, tips his ha Louise exactly like the man he saw on television.
... Well, ain't you the gentleman this mornin'... (a pause)
... gotta go now, Chance...
(resumes working)
Yes.
You're gonna need somebody, someone's gotta be around for you, boy...  (he keeps working)
... You oughta find yourself a lady, Chance...  (she smiles slightly, with caring)
But I guess it oughta be an old lady, 'cause you ain't gonna do a young one any good, not with that little thing of yours...  (she reaches out, puts a hand on his shoulder)
... You're always gonna be a little boy, ain't you?  (he smiles, keeps working)
... Goodbye, Chance... Louise gives his shoulder a squeeze, turns and moves towa the house.
(as she goes)
Goodbye, Louise. Louise waves as she enters the townhouse. Chance tips his once again as she disappears.

Louise enters the hallway, picks up a couple of suit case waiting by the door. She stops as she sees TWO MEN in whi carrying a stretcher down the main staircase. She notices ease with which they bring the Old Man's body down the stairs.
... He used to be a big man... 'Spose he wasted away to about nothin'...  (a beat - then she talks to the body of the old Man)

... I guess I'll be goin' off to find me some folks, Old Man... I'm not batty enough to stay around this neighborhood any longer... The stretcher bearers move to the front door. Louise step front of them.
(to stretcher bearers)
Wait up! I'm goin' out that door first. Louise takes one more look at the covered body, then open the front door, leaves.
The TV plays offstage as Chance washes up in the bathroom finishes, comes into the bedroom, takes a pair of house slippers from his closet, turns off the television and le the room.
Chance, carrying his slippers, crosses through the layer fresh snow to the townhouse.

Chance, wearing the slippers, enters and sits at his plac He turns on the TV, puts the napkin on his lap. He watche for a moment, then turns, looks for Louise. She does not appear so he resumes watching TV. He changes channels, vi a wildly exciting FOOTBALL game. At a peak in the excitem he again switches channels. Chance watches TV News covera of the PRESIDENT of the United States greeting foreign dignitaries at the White House. CLOSE SHOTS on television reveal that the President uses two-handed handshake when meeting his guests. Unconscious Chance grips one hand with the other, the scene on TV see to have 'sunk into' his mind.

A key is heard in the lock. The door opens and THOMAS FRANKLIN and SALLY HAYES enter. Franklin, an attorney, is his late thirties, carries a large briefcase. Hayes is younger, attractive, also an attorney. She totes a briefc has the look of a modern, liberated woman. Hayes appears be surprised at the interior of the house.
(looks around)
... This is another world, Tom - I never would have believed it...
Yeah... He and my father used to ride together back in the thirties... Fox hunting... Before I was born...
... Would you take me on a tour?
Gladly...  (he smiles)
... The safe is in Mr. Jennings' bedroom, that'll be stop number one. Franklin puts a hand on Hayes' shoulder as they,go off do the hall.
Chance still watches TV, waits for Louise to serve him. Franklin and Hayes appear in the doorway of the dining ro They are both surprised to see Chance.
... Why... Hello, we thought we heard something...  (moves to Chance, hand outstretched)
I'm Thomas Franklin. Chance remains seated, takes Franklin's hand warmly in bo of his like the President did on TV.
Hello, Thomas... I'm Chance, the gardener.
(a beat)
... The gardener?  (thinks it's a joke, laughs)
... Yes, of course... Mr. Chance, this is Ms. Hayes. Hayes moves to shake Chance's hand.
Mr. Chance, I'm very pleased to meet you.
(doesn't rise, again shakes with both hands)
Yes. Chance turns back to the TV and Hayes and Franklin exchan looks.
(after an uneasy pause)
... We're with Franklin, Jennings and Roberts, the law firm handling the estate.
(a smile, totally at ease)
Yes, Thomas - I understand. Another period of silence. Franklin and Hayes seem perple
... Are you waiting for someone? An appointment?
Yes. I'm waiting for my lunch.
Your lunch? You have a luncheon appointment here?
Yes. Louise will bring me lunch.
Louise?... The maid?... (a look to Hayes)
But she should have left earlier today...
(smiles at Hayes)
I see...
(a beat)
... You've quite a sense of humor, Mr. Chance - but all kidding aside, may I ask just what you are doing here?
I live here.
You live here? (a look to Hayes)
... We don't have any record of that.
Yes. It's very cold outside today, isn't it, Thomas?
(a beat)
... How long have you been living here?
Ever since I can remember, since I was a child.
(doubting)
Since you were a child?
Yes, Thomas. I have always been here. I have always worked in the garden.
... Then you really are a gardener?
Yes.
Your appearance doesn't suggest that at all, Mr. Chance.
Oh. Thank you.
Do you have any proof of your employment, Mr. Chance - any checks from the deceased, any contracts or documents?
No.
How were you compensated for these duties you say you performed?
Compensated...?
How were you paid?
I was given meals, and a home...
What about money?
I never needed money. Franklin steps to the TV, turns it off.
Mr. Chance, perhaps you could show us some identification with your address -- a Driver's License, a credit card, checkbook?
No, I do not have any of those.
Then how about medical records? Could you give us the name of your doctor, or your dentist?
I have no need for a doctor or dentist. I have never been ill. I have never been allowed outside of this house, and, except for Joe, I have never had any visitors.
... Joe? Who's Joe?
(turns TV back on)
Joe Saracini. He was a mason that did some repairs on the brickwork at the rear of the house. That was in 1952.
(changes channels)
Yes. I remember when he came. He was very fat and had short hair and showed me some pictures from a funny little book.
Some pictures...?
Yes. Of men and women.
Mr. Chance, that was twenty-seven years ago.
Yes and the Old Man used to come to my garden. He would read and rest there.
Come now, Mr. Jennings had been bedridden for thirty-five years, since he fractured his spine.
Yes, Thomas, that is correct. Then he stopped visiting my garden.
(a beat)
... We shall need some proof of your having resided here, Mr. Chance.
You have me, I am here. What more proof do you need? Franklin and Hayes exchange looks.
Chance puts on his snow-boots as Franklin and Hayes conti their questioning.
Have you served in the Army?
No, Thomas. But I have seen the Army on television.
How about taxes, Mr. Chance, surely you must have paid taxes?
No. Chance picks up his slippers and leads the attorneys outs
Chance describes his garden with pride as they walk towar the rear building.
(points)
Those trees were very young when I first arrived.
Are you related to the deceased, Mr. Chance?
No, I don't think so. And I have planted and shaped all the hedges, and in the springtime you will be able to see my flowers.
Might you have a birth certificate, Mr. Chance?
No. (points to wall)
That's where Joe fixed the bricks. They arrive at the rear building and Chance opens the doo the garage. Franklin and Hayes follow him inside.
Franklin and Hayes are taken aback by the touring car.
(admires car)
... Do you drive this, Mr. Chance?
No, Thomas. I have never been in an automobile.
(amazed)
You never been in a car? Chance is silent for a moment, he blushes slightly.
... Well... From time to time I did sit in it... Just in here... It hasn't been outside since the Old Man hurt himself. (he turns)
I live in here. Chance moves toward his room, Franklin and Hayes follow.
Chance sits on the bed to remove his boots as Hayes and Franklin inspect the room.
The Old Man gave me nice television sets, this one has remote control. (he turns it on with the remote)
He has one just like it.
Mr. Chance, the fact remains that we have no information of your having any connection with the deceased.
Yes, I understand. Chance puts on his slippers, crosses to the closet, opens door. It is filled with men's wear.
I am allowed to go to the attic and select any of the Old Man's suits. They all fit me very well. I can also take his shirts, shoes and coats.
It is quite amazing how those clothes have come back into style.
Yes. I have seen styles on television.
(getting back to business)
What are your plans now, Mr. Chance?
I would like to stay and work in my garden. Chance turns to watch TV. Franklin takes Hayes to a side the room.
(quietly)
... What do you make of all this?
I really don't know, Tom - he seems so honest and simple... In a way, he's quite charming...
(looks at Chance)
... Yeah...
... It's very bizarre - I don't know what to think...
Well... He's either very, very bright or very, very dense - he's hard to figure... (he unzips briefcase)
... Let's just keep everything legal. Franklin takes out some papers, approaches Chance.
Mr. Chance, assuming what you say is the truth, I would like to know what sort of claim you are planning to make against the deceased's estate.
(does not understand)
I'm fine, Thomas. The garden is a healthy one. There is no need for a claim.
Good. That's good. Then if you would please sign a paper to that effect. Franklin hands the release to Chance but Chance does not it.
No, Thomas. I don't know how to sign.
Come now, Mr. Chance.
(smiles)
I have no claim, Thomas.
But you won't sign, correct?
Correct.
Very well, Mr. Chance - if you insist on dragging this matter on... But I must inform you this house will be closed tomorrow at noon. If indeed, you do reside here, you will have to move out.
Move out? I don't understand, Thomas.
I think you do, Mr. Chance. However, I will reiterate, this house is closed and you must leave... (he gives Chance his business card)
Call me if you change your mind about signing. (turns to Hayes)
C'mon, Sally - let's grab a bite...
(a smile to Chance)
Good day, Mr. Chance.
(returns smile)
Good day, Sally. Chance watches as they leave, then puts Franklin's card o desk without ever looking at it and turns to stare at television.

A large attic filled with the Old Man's possessions of th past. Chance enters, turns on an old black-and-white TV w a magnifying lens attached to the front. As it plays, he selects a fine leather suitcase from several, takes a han made suit from a long rack.
The TV is on as Chance packs his belongings.
Chance, very nicely dressed, comes out of the rear buildi carrying his suitcase. He stops on occasion to inspect hi garden as he walks toward the townhouse.
Chance is reluctant to open the front door. After some hesitation, he gathers up his courage, opens it and steps outside, closing the door behind him.

Chance stops short on the front steps; the townhouse is situated in a decaying ghetto. The snow is a dirty grey, houses adjoining have their win shattered, are smeared with grafitti. Chance tries to ret to the safety of the townhouse, but the door is locked. H stands on the steps for a moment, then moves to the trash laden sidewalk. He stops, ponders which way to go, finall makes up his mind and moves off to his left.

The buildings are crumbling, rusted out cars line the str A group of Black people huddle together in threadbare stu furniture on the sidewalk, a fire burning between them fo warmth. Chance rounds the corner, walks up to them. He st by them, smiles. They stare back, no sign of friendship i their faces. Chance nods politely to them, then walks awa down the sidewalk.
A group of eight to ten hard-core ghetto youths hang out corner. Other passersby give them a wide berth, they are unapproachable. Chance nears the group, approaches.
(friendly)
... Excuse me, would you please tell me where I could find a garden to work in? They turn to him as one, silent, amazed that this White trespasser would intrude on their jiving.
(after a beat)
... There is much to be done during the winter, I must start the seeds for the spring, I must work the soil... One of the Black youths, LOLO, interrupts Chance.
What you growin', man? The leader of the gang, ABBAZ, shuts up Lolo with an elbo and moves menacingly forward.
(nose to nose with Chance)
... What you doin' here, boy?
I had to leave my garden. I want to find another.
Bullshit. Who sent you here, boy? Did that chickenshit asshole Raphael send you here, boy?
No. Thomas Franklin told me that I had to leave the Old Man's house, he's dead now, you know...

Dead, my ass! Now get this, honkie - you go tell Raphael that I ain't takin' no jive from no Western Union messenger! You tell that asshole, if he got somethin' to tell me to get his ass here himself!  (edges closer to Chance)
You got that, boy? Chance smiles at Abbaz and reaches into his pocket.
Yes. I understand.  (he takes out his remote control TV changer)
If I see Raphael I will tell him. Chance points the changer at Abbaz and clicks it three ti tries to change the picture. Abbaz immediately pulls out switchblade, whips the blade open.
(holds knife at Chance)
Now, move, honkie! Before I cut your white ass! Chance, disappointed that the changer did not work, retur it to his pocket.
Yes. Of course. (as he leaves)

Good day. Abbaz, Lolo and the gang watch him go, then begin to buzz with excitement: "Who the fuck died?" "Why'd he pull that changer on us, man?" "The Old Man died, must be Papa Joe! "He's some weird honkie, man."
A Bulletin board affixed to a storefront in Chinatown. Ch gazes at the notes pinned to it, written in Chinese. Smil he turns from it, walks on through the area.
A street lined with adult book stores, X-rated movies and strip joints. An elderly Black woman approaches carrying bag of groceries. Chance steps in front of the woman, sto her.

I'm very hungry now. Would you please bring me my lunch? The woman looks up to Chance, becomes very frightened. Sh turns and half-runs into a sleazy bar for safety. Chance watches after her for a moment, then continues along.
Chance stands looking through a chain-link fence watching some teenage boys playing basketball. He bangs on the fen calls to them.
I have seen your game! I have watched Elvin Hayes play it many times! They call him "Big E!" The boys ignore him, Chance walks away.
Chance walks down the center meridian of a divided street seems oblivious to the automobiles passing on either side the background can be seen the Washington Monument.

Chance seems stumped on which way to go. He looks up one street, then the other, has no idea where they lead. He turns, looks behind him and sees a large statue of Benito Juarez pointing. Chance smiles and goes off in the direct that Benito points.
Tourists are gathered around gaping through the fence at White House. Chance is turned the other way, inspecting the branches o dying tree. Chance moves to a POLICEMAN standing nearby.
Excuse me... (points to tree)
... That tree is very sick. It should be cared for. The Policeman looks at the tree, then at Chance, figures man dressed that well must be important.
Yes sir. I'll report it right away.
Yes. That would be a good thing to do. Good day.
Good day. The Policeman takes out his walkie-talkie as Chance walks away.

A fashionable area. Expensive shops, well-kept streets an sidewalks. A television store has caught Chance's eye. He stands by the display window, looks in at a dozen or so c TVs, all turned on, playing various channels. A video cam points outward from a corner of the window and is focused the sidewalk to allow potential customers to see themselv live on an Advent TV. Chance is intrigued by his own imag He poses, lifts one arm, then the other to make sure that is really him on television. He moves forward, smiles, th moves slowly backward, notices himself become smaller on screen. He steps back off the curb, frowns as his likenes disappears from frame on the Advent. Standing between two parked cars, Chance takes out his remote control, clicks at the Advent. Four or five other sets in the window chan channels, but he does not reappear on the giant screen. A does this, the car to his,left, a large, American-made limousine, backs up. The car bumps Chance, pins him again the car to his right. Chance cries out in pain, drops his suitcase, his changer, and bangs his hand on the trunk of limo. The chauffeur, DAVID, and the liveryman, JEFFREY, immediately jump from the car, run back to Chance.
I'm very sorry, sir... I... David and Jeffrey reach out to help, but Chance is wedged solidly between the two cars.
(in pain)
... I can't move... My leg...
(rushes back to limo)
... My Lord...
This is terrible, sir -  I hope you're not badly injured...
No. I'm not badly injured. But my leg is very sore. David pulls the car forward, freeing Chance. A few bystan begin to gather as Jeffrey helps Chance to the sidewalk.
Can you walk? It's not broken, is it?
(leans against limo, holds leg)
It's very sore. David gets out of the car, comes back.
Perhaps I should call an ambulance. A BYSTANDER interrupts.
Somebody ought to call the police!
(looks over, smiles)

There's no need for police, it's just my leg. During this, the rear door of the limo opens and EVE RAND steps out. Eve is in her late thirties, has the look of a traditional New England lady. She watches as Jeffrey tend Chance.
I don't think we should call anyone just yet, it may not even be all that serious.
(obviously hurting)
I agree.
Let's have a look, do you mind?
Of course. I would like to look. Chance bends, raises his trouser leg. A red-bluish swolle bruise, three inches in diameter, is forming on his calf.
It's starting to swell, is it painful?
Yes. Eve moves closer to Chance, looks at the bruise.
(to Chance)
... Won't you let us do something for you? Your leg should be examined, we could take you to a hospital.
(smiles at Eve)
There's no need for a hospital.
Why, there certainly is. You must see a doctor, I insist on it. Please, let us take you. Eve turns to get back into the limo. David goes with her hold the door.
I'm terribly sorry, Mrs. Rand, I never saw the man.
Oh, I don't think it was anyone's fault, David.
Thank you, ma'am. Chance is hesitant about getting in the car. Jeffrey offe helping hand.
Please, sir.
I've never ridden in an automobile.
(a beat)
I assure you, sir, David is a very careful driver. Please, won't you let us take you?
(looks at the car, then decides)
... Yes. You can take me.
Very good. Jeffrey assists Chance into the rear seat of the limo.
(as he gets in)
... My suitcase.

Yes sir. I'll take care of that. Jeffrey closes the door, goes back to pick up Chance's suitcase, does not notice the remote control. As Jeffrey Chance's bag into the trunk, we see the personalized lice plate "RAND l."
Chance and Eve settle in the back seat. As they talk, Dav starts up the limo, Jeffrey joins him in front and the li pulls out into traffic.
I hope you're comfortable.
Yes. I am.

These can be such trying situations everyone seems to make such a to-do over a simple little accident. Of course, they can be very frightening, and I must apologize for David, he's never had an accident before.
Yes. He's a very careful driver.
... Why, yes, he is... Is your leg feeling any better?
It's feeling better, but it's still very sore.
I see. (a thought)
... Say, would you mind seeing our family doctor?
(doesn't understand)
Your family doctor?
Yes. My husband has been very ill. His doctor and nurses are staying with us. Those hospitals can be so impersonal - why, it might be hours before you are treated...
I agree.
Fine, it will save a lot of unnecessary fuss and it will be so much more pleasant for you... (leans forward)
David, we'll just go on home. Jeffrey, would you call and let them know?

Yes ma'am. Eve presses a button, the glass partition closes. As the window rolls up behind him, Jeffrey dials the limo teleph There is a moment of silence. Eve, still a bit on edge fr the accident and feeling a bit uncomfortable with a stran in the car, presses another button. The limo's bar moves revealing a row of decanters and glasses.
Would you care for a drink?
Yes. Thank you. As Eve pours cognac into a monogrammed crystal glass, Cha notices the limo's TV set.
I would like to watch television.
(a bit surprised)
Oh? Certainly... She hands Chance the cognac, turns on the TV.
Oh, by the way - I'm Eve Rand.
Hello, Eve.  Chance takes a sip of the cognac, is not accustomed to alcohol, coughs. There is another moment of silence.
May I ask your name?
(with a slight cough)
My name is Chance.
Pardon me, was that Mr. Chance?
(still indistinct)
No. I'm a gardener.
Oh... Mr. Gardiner... Mr. Chauncey Gardiner... You're not related to Basil and Perdita Gardiner are you?
No, Eve. I'm not related to Basil and Perdita.

Oh. Well, they're just a wonderful couple, we've been friends for years. We visit their island quite often. Chance reaches out to change the channel on the TV, sudde realizes he doesn't have his remote control. He starts go through his pockets, searches for it.
Did you lose something?
Yes. I lost my remote control.
Oh... Well, I'm very sorry... Another pause, Chance reaches out, changes channels on TV
... I'll feel so relieved after Dr. Allenby examines your leg. After that, David can run you on home, or to your office or wherever you'd prefer...  (Chance still watches TV)
... Is there anything special you would like to watch?

(laughs)

... I don't know what you've heard about me, Chauncey, but I'm sure you know everything there is to know. Cigar? Rand holds out humidor to Chance.

... No, of course you don't. Excuse me for being so presumptuous. No man knows everything about another man - however, very few are honest enough to admit it.

Thank you, Robert. Rand lights his own cigar, then hands an ornate lighter t Chance.
(picks up pool cue, weakly strokes the balls)

A good woman, Mrs. Aubrey.

Yes, I did.

... (staring at Chance)
... Spring and summer... (confused)
Yes, I see... Fall and winter. (smiles at Chance)
Yes, indeed... (a beat)
Could you go through that one more time, please, Mr. Gardiner?

Yes. That is correct.
(pleased)
